Posts.Content: My wife had a picc line inserted yesterday, the sleeve is not great and continually needs adjusting.  She has just  noticed a small amount of dried blood there. What to do?
Posts.Title: Picc leakage

Posts.Content: There is no real long-term hope, we were told as much about a month ago...'We'll keep you as well as possible for as long as possible'
Posts.Title: Getting really scary now.

Posts.Content: A plan was in place, a picc line in Tuesday and treatment on Weds then 3 weekly. Well it went in on the 2nd attempt but where it went seems to be a mystery, 'Vanishes into the mist' was the phrase used. We'll have to get the oncologist to have a look, she'll be in Thursday, go home.  We're not so sure it had been there a long time, it was so large by the time it was discovered, and has seemingly grown rapidly since. Good luck with your treatment
Posts.Title: Getting really scary now.

Posts.Content: ...but there are so, so, so many people in this position... so many 'Newbies' to the forum here.. I found it overwhelming and barely looked in here. Thanks for reading and replying. I wish you all well with your own battles.
Posts.Title: Getting really scary now.

Posts.Content: My wife was diagnosed a month ago when "it" was about 4 cm, no treatment started and "it" has grown alot

Posts.Content: I'm clearly going through the frustrated/angry phase, sorry.
Posts.Title: Getting really scary now.

Posts.Content: Letter to the GP from the 'Team' Dec 2015 "We discussed your patient at our recent Multidisciplinary Team Meeting following the MRI scan of her pelvis, which was arranged by you as she presented with left hip pain. As you know she had locally advanced breast cancer, T3, NO, Grade 3 and underwent neoadjuvant chemotherapy and subsequent mastectomy. Unfortunately the MRI scan suggested evidence of metastatic disease. The CA- 125 is also elevated. She had further imaging with a CT scan and this shows evidence of lymphadenopathy in her left axilla. The previous seroma in the right breast area, which was drained, seemed to have increased in size. There was evidence of mediastinal lymphadenopathy as well as a right upper lobe, 1.7 cm, soft, lobular mass, representative of a pulmonary metastasis. There was also irregularity of the liver suggestive of hepatic metastasis and extensive retroperitoneal adenopathy. There was extensive bone disease as described on the MRI scan. She has been referred for an Orthopaedic opinion and has also been referred to Exeter. The summary of the CT scan was marked progression with extensive left axillary, hilar, mediastinal and retroperitoneal adenopathy with lung, liver and bony metastasis. She also has masses in her ovaries which have been reviewed by the Gynaecology Team and are probably part and parcel of the same process. As mentioned, her CA- 125 was elevated. We felt she would need further assessment of her bony hip problems and possibly stabilisation and radiotherapy, further chemotherapy and a gynaecological opinion about the current situation. We would be happy to meet up with her at some stage when she is having further oncological assessment."
Posts.Title: Getting really scary now.

Posts.Content: Thank you, glad you are getting sorted, we are just out on that road.
